intro: Biscutella laevigata var. dentata, commonly known as the serrated biscuitroot, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of the western United States. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many flowering plants with distinctive four-petaled flowers. The plant features small, lance-shaped leaves with serrated edges, and its flowers are typically pale yellow or white. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine environments. The species is valued for its ornamental appeal and its ability to stabilize soil in harsh, high-altitude conditions.
